In Khartoum, the faces of a martyred capital: 'War cannot kill ideas, nor love'
Subhead: War in Sudan: A Trapped Nation (3/6). Le Monde's reporters traveled through the Sudanese capital, which for two years was the epicenter of the conflict. They met with residents, who recounted how they survived despite fear and violence.

Ban on social media for under-15s: What we know about the government's plan
Subhead: In addition to banning smartphones in high schools, a new law aims to block the youngest from accessing social media platforms. President Emmanuel Macron mentioned the topic during his New Year's address, and Parliament will debate the measure at the start of the year.

Title: Investigators focus on sparklers on top of champagne bottles for deadly Swiss bar fire
Subhead: The bar owner insisted that all safety standards were followed. Authorities warned it could take days to identify everyone who perished.

Title: In Rio de Janeiro, New Year's Eve celebration sparks debate over secularism
Subhead: Mayor Eduardo Paes (centrist) set aside one of the city's music stages for gospel, a genre closely tied to evangelical worship. He has faced criticism for allegedly courting evangelical voters ahead of the October state governor election.

Title: China's plan for London mega-embassy stokes controversy
Subhead: Beijing acquired Royal Mint Court in 2018 with the aim of relocating its embassy in the United Kingdom there. Housing Minister Steve Reed had until December 10 to make a decision on this major project, but the deadline was postponed for the third consecutive time to January 2026.

Early Christian fresco depicting Jesus as the Good Shepherd discovered in Turkey
Subhead: One month after Pope Leo XIV's visit, Turkish authorities announced the discovery in Iznik, Anatolia, of a depiction of Christ in a well-preserved burial chamber.

Title: Physical activity can reduce the risk of death: 'It's very hard to find a drug that can do that'
Subhead: Longevity physician Peter Attia highlights in his book the importance of physical exercise to combat what he calls the 'four horsemen': cardiovascular disease, cancer, dementia, and metabolic disorders.

Title: In Brazil, love vibrates at the heart of society
Subhead: Traditions around love have long spilled beyond the realm of intimacy to shape the social, political and even collective identity of the country, writes Le Monde's correspondent Bruno Meyerfeld in his final dispatch.
